Key Arguments: The bill is fundamentally misconceived and an attack on free speech.
It lacks a sound cost/benefit analysis regarding its impact on democracy and society.
There are significant practical difficulties in defining and enforcing misinformation and disinformation.
The bill is anti-democratic and discriminates against smaller media voices.
It exempts government from accountability, which undermines trust.
The bill imposes a regulatory burden and has a chilling effect on free speech.
It grants unaccountable power to bureaucrats to determine truth and harm.
The bill could be misused to suppress dissent and enforce government-approved narratives.
Notable Quotes: The Bill is fundamentally misconceived, an implicit if not explicit attack on free speech, radically anti-democratic, multi-flawed and should be withdrawn.

The Bill flies directly in the face of one the central ideological advances of Western Civilisation over the last two millennia, namely, the right of individuals to freely believe, speak, hear, read, and write.

This Bill, while masquerading as legislation to protect the public, despite whatever was in the minds of its progenitors and framers, is in fact an instrument further empowering the executive government to suppress dissent from approved 'facts', narratives, and opinions.
This proposed legislation appears to have been formulated and proposed without adequate in depth harm/benefit analysis.
